text: A bedroom stuck in the 1970's. Felt wallpaper, cigarette smoke stains, thick dust. Pictures everywhere of a MAN (VINCENT) and a WOMAN (SANDY) in love. They couldn’t look happier. Young, full of life. On the bed, a Russian woman with a tortured Brooklyn accent, DAKA, rides on top of someone we’1ll soon meet. Daka is lost in her 30s, rough, tattooed, too much makeup, and somewhere underneath it all...beautiful. Furthermore, she’s pregnant. Who knows how long, she’s so damn skinny. Grinding away.

You eat the breakfast yet? She’s talking to VINCENT (mostly VIN.) Whom she’s riding. He’s the guy from the pictures, although now in his 60s/70s. Beat-to-hell, raw, irreverent. He gave up on life years ago.
(puffing a cigarette) You didn’t eat?
I forget.
How do you forget to eat?
It happens so. Vincent returns his gaze to...the TV on top of his dresser. An old Abbott & Costello movie is playing. Daka adjusts herself, continues grinding on Vincent. Then...

You want go to breakfast? Sure. INT. NAT’S BROOKLYN DINER - LATER A greasy spoon in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Vincent and Daka are in a booth eating breakfast. Daka is scarfing down Huevos Rancheros, like she hasn’t eaten in days.
I get reflux just looking at you.
They have pill for this.
Bastards have a pill for everything. That’s a fact, lady. Killing us all, ten milligrams at a time. Vincent sifts through his pill pouch. Pulls out a dozen or so...the day’s dose.
Where’s the water? Didn’t I ask for water?
Ask fuck again.
Coming here twenty years, still can’t get their shit together. Calling off to a Mexican server (JESUS.)
Jesus. Aqua. Pills. Jesus smiles, nods.
I never take this pills.
Just crack and meth. That’s a better plan.
Fuck you, Vin. Stay off me. She reaches across the table for his toast.
You want this toast. Jesus returns with a glass of water. Lots of ice.
Here you go, Mr. Vincent.
Can you put more ice in it? I want to make sure I choke while I’m swallowing my poison. Jesus is confused.
He don’t want this ice.
Oh. Si.
Yeah. Oh, si. Just like everyday I come in here. Aqua no hielo. No one really knows what to say. They've heard it all before. Daily.
Uno momento, Mr. Vincent. Jesus walks off, nonplussed.
Uno momento. Vin takes a pill, swallows.
What did Jesus say to the Mexicans before he left?
This I don’t know.
Don’t do anything till I get back. Daka doesn’t laugh.
You speak for Jesus is not right.
Really. From you? Vin takes another pill. Swallows.
Standard bank. Vin'’s car’s parked outside. A very old convertible MG Spider in shit shape. INT. THE BANK — CONTINUOUS Vin’s sitting across from a mortgage counselor, TERRY. He’s reviewing paperwork.
(pointing) That one there. Says the line’s been frozen.  Terry shuffles.
Uh-huh. Got it. Yes. Let’s see...so...with these reverse mortgages you can only borrow a percentage of the equity you have in the house. That’s called the loan-to-value.
Don’t need a financial seminar. I own the damn thing outright. 40 years.

Yes. Yes. Well...you did. But now, Since you’ve been getting monthly payments from us for the last... (searches the papers) eight years...you’ve reached the cash out limit. That’s that loan- to-value thing I just mentioned.
The house is worth-

It was worth. Whatever it was worth. And I’m sure you know housing prices have fallen dramatically since the financial crisis. Right. Unless you’ve been living under a rock. His attempt at humor...not appreciated.
You do stand-up? Vin rises.
This is my life here, pal. I need that money.
I’m sorry, Mr. Canatella. There’s really nothing I can do. It is what it is.
Everybody's says that now. You know what it means, “You're fucked, and will remain fucked.” He walks off.
I’m closing my accounts forthwith. You don’t get my business another day.
Vin waits in line, steaming. Ding. An electronic arrow points him to TELLER WINDOW #23.
Vin hands TELLER #23 his ATM card.
I want to close this account.
I’m sorry to hear that, sir. May I ask why?
Lady. You're just a spoke on a wheel, trying to make a living like the rest of us schmucks. I don’t want to tell you to go fuck yourself. Let’s just leave it at that.
Okay. Tap, tap, tap on the keyboard.
That’s one hundred twelve dollars and fourteen cents.
Small bills.
No, sir...you’re overdrawn that much.
What’s that mean?
It means you don’t-
I know what overdrawn means.
We've sent several notices.
So. I can’t close my account.

You can, when you get it back to zero. Vin takes his card. What’s to say. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Vin labors into the car. Daka is waiting in the passenger seat. He hands her a few crumpled bills.
What’s this?
What’s what?
My shit is not lay-a-way. I am no JC Penny. Fuck face.
I’m a little tight right now. You know I’m good for it. Daka looks him over.
I don’t make like before, Vin. Only few freaks like the belly. Understand. She gets out of the car.
Have to save for maternity leave. You asshole. She heads off down the sidewalk.
See you next week.
Extras when you do. Daka moves on, bag in hand, adjusting her junk. Vin drives off. A few NEIGHBORHOOD MEN whistle at Daka. She yells back at them.
I’m not dog! Fuck face.
The local dive bar. SMOKERS outside litter the sidewalk. The windows are painted with “Happy New Year” greetings.

Old neon. Older PATRONS. Vin sits at the bar next to LINDA and GUS, a weathered married couple in their late 60s. They’re dressed to the nines. The hanging TV set plays New Year’s Eve coverage from around the country. They're all fairly lit...although Vin’s in a class by himself. Very thick tongued.
You have a good Christmas, Vin?
(slurring) Best Christmas I ever had. No people. No presents. No bullshit. Just celebrating the birth of the baby Jesus. Tips his tumbler to heaven.
Ah, you don’t mean that, Mister.
What do you know what I mean, Linda? You a psychic now?
Ay, ease up there, Vinny. We're just talking.
You should get a talk show. You’re so damn good at it. The “Linda and Gus Just Fucking Talking Talk Show.” Vin flags the bartender, ROGER.
Rog. Another Maker's. Roger steps over.
Vin...we got three hours till the ball drops there. Why don’t we give it a break for a minute.
Give what a break?
The liquor.
You're not gonna serve me?
For a minute.
You know how much money I’ve spent in this dump over the years? Roger tries to keep it smooth.
Don't be like that, Vin. I’m watching out for you here.
Watching out for me? Vin stands, wobbles. He’s drunker than even he realized.
You serve poison to people everyday. So they can die while they’re alive. Now you’re watching out...is that right? Gus stands, tries to help Vin.
Let me give you a ride home.
Don’t touch me, Gus. Do not touch me. I will drive home drunk like I’ve done every night Roger here’s been watching out for me. Vin pushes free, walks to the door.

Happy New Year. He’s out. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER The Spider whips into the driveway. Hits the picket fence on the neighbor's border. Crash. It topples. Hits his own mailbox on the other side. Crash. It flies onto the lawn. He puts the top up. Vin shuts the car off. Sits for a minute. Then steps out and swerves to the toppled mailbox. Gets on all fours, opens the door, gets the mail...pounds of it.

Vin stares at a mountain of unopened mail, overflowing a basket. He empties the basket onto the floor, then tosses the new mail into the empty basket. All sorted. INT. VIN’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Vin puts his feet up on a weathered coffee table, watching TV from his paisley pattered couch. The decor is feminine inspired, twenty years ago. Coverage of the Times Square New Year's Eve Celebration plays. Vin’s cat, FELIX THE CAT, jumps onto his lap. Starts to pur.
There you are. Where’d you go tonight, ha? You out catting around... He rubs the cat all over. His only love.
I bet you’re hungry, aren’t you? He takes Felix in his arms, shuffles to the kitchen.

The kitchen is trashed: dishes to China, mold, stacks of newspapers a decade old. Vin opens a can of gourmet cat food. Dumps it in a bowl. Felix waits patiently on the counter...the food arrives. He eats like there’s no tomorrow. Vin needs another drink. He holds his tumbler to the ice maker in the fridge door. It grinds. No ice. He opens the freezer door and grabs a glob of ice cubes stuck together, puts them on the counter. Grabs a hammer from the junk drawer. BANG. BANG. He smashes the ice into pieces, chips fly. BANG! He hits his finger.

UGHHHH. Shit. AHHHH. Vin stumbles with the pain. His foot gets ever so close to an ice chip on the tile floor... Slip. Flip. Smack. Vin flies up in the air, lands on the floor. Crack! His head hits the tile hard. He’s out. Or dead.  10. Felix looks at his owner. Jumps down beside him. Laps up some blood.

TV insert. The ball is dropping in Times Square. 5, 4, 3, 2, 1. Happy New Year. PEOPLE hug, kiss, celebrate. FADE TO BLACK. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - THE NEXT MORNING MEN screaming in Spanish. We pan away from Vin’s house, over towards the source of the racket. In the neighbor’s driveway, a moving truck is backing into the drive and ripping tree limbs along the way. Vin’s tree limbs. A LATIN MOVER is screaming instructions to the LATIN DRIVER.
Alto! Alto! You hit the tree, man. Come on!
Meda, I can’t see it! He notices the roof: pealed like a sardine can.

You broke the roof! Ay Dios mio! They fight on. INT. KITCHEN - VIN’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Vin'’s where we left him: face down on the kitchen floor. A small pool of blood sits stagnant under his face. The yelling outside irks him to consciousness.
Shut up out there. People are sleeping. He groans. Holds himself up. Felix the Cat stares from a safe distance. Vin sees the blood.

Ah, piss. He feels his face, and for the first time we see it: he looks like a prize fighter after the twelfth round.  11. A gash above his eye is the origin of the blood. It probably needs stitches. He’1ll never get them. Vin sits there for a second, collects himself. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Vin walks outside, searching for the commotion. He shields the sun from his eyes. The fighting Movers are still at it.
Hey! Hey! What’s the problem? This is a neighborhood. People are sleeping. The Movers stop. Stare.
You comprende?! Nothing.
Habla English?
We speak English, senor.
What the hell are you doing here? Vin looks up, notices the tree ripped.
What the?!? That’s my tree you assholes hit?! There's a large tree limb sitting on Vin’s car and across the fence (which he knocked down last night.)

And my fence! My damn car!?! Silence. VINCENT (CONT’D) Do you speak English!?! Just then a car pulls up, parks in front of the house. A WOMAN in her late thirties steps out. This is MAGGIE, Vin’s new neighbor. She'd be prettier if she weren’t always so worried.
I’m calling the cops. Vin heads inside.  12.
Excuse me... He turns.
What do you want?
I'm Maggie. I guess I’m your new neighbor. Really.
So.
Yes. We’re moving in today.
I noticed that. These dipshits with you?
They're with the moving company. Maggie walks to the fence, stands on her side. Looks around.
Oh, boy.
Oh, shit...more like it. That fence is twenty years old. The car’s forty. And the tree’s older than me.
I’m really sorry. I don’t know what to...this is not the way to meet. She turns to the Movers.
Did you guys do this?
Of course, they did it. What are you stupid? Look at the scene. Maggie doesn’t take kindly to being called stupid.

Excuse me. There’s no need to be rude. Okay. I’m just moving in here. I hired this company. Okay. Accidents happen.  13. A LITTLE BOY comes up to Maggie’s side. This is OLIVER. Twelve. Frail. Four eyes. Painfully awkward and very sensitive. He’s one of those invisible types.
Accidents happen. What’re you a fucking adjuster? Maggie puts her arm around Oliver.
Do you mind, mister? Vin looks at Oliver. Absorbs him.
That car’s an antique, missy. Worth a lot of money. She looks at the car. More like a piece of shit.
I'll figure out how to-

You. You don’t have any money. No offense. You don’t look like you do. And I'll bet Chico and the Man over there are “off the books.” No, thank you, blondie, I’1l sue the moving company. Vin walks off.
You can buck up for the tree and the fence. He hits the front door. Oliver looks up at his mom.
That’s our new neighbor.
Yep.

It’s gonna be a long life. INT. MAGGIE & OLIVER’S HOUSE - NIGHT Oliver's bedroom. The room has a bed in it, little else. The evening ritual is in progress: bedtime book time. Although...Oliver is the one reading: “The Giving Tree.” Maggie’s on a beanbag on the floor, nursing a Chardonnay.  14.

(reading) “I wish that I could give you something, but I have nothing left.” I am just an old stump. “I don't need very much now," said the boy. “Just a quiet place to sit and rest. I am very tired." "Well," said the tree, straightening herself up as much as she could, "Well, an old stump is good for sitting and resting. Come, Boy, sit down. Sit down and rest." And the boy did. And the tree was happy. Maggie drinks her wine. She gets
God, that’s depressing. up.
No, it’s not. The old tree was made to give. So to be able to give everything and have nothing left is the best life the tree could ever have. She tucks Oliver into bed. Kisses his forehead.
That’s a nice way to look at it. Need you to catch the bus tomorrow.
It’s my first day.
Mine too. Can’t be late. Maggie goes to turn off the light.
Where’s the bus line?
Get on the internet in the morning. You're good at that. Good night, love.
Night. She turns the light off. Oliver settles into the darkness.  15.
Bus stop. Maggie’s old Corolla sits in the bus lane. Oliver’s outside the door, leaning in the window. He’s dressed in a Catholic School uniform. Maggie hands him a lunch box.
Peanut butter and bananas.
Thanks, mom.
Snack money in the pocket. You have your key?
Yes.
Map?
Yes.
What time you get out?
Straight home, ‘kay. Start your homework.
Okay. A bus pulls up behind Maggie.
(re: the bus) This is yours. See you tonight.
Wait. Ma...you’re not picking me-
I’m in the bus lane, Oliver. Be good. Okay. I don’t need another ticket. Maggie blows him a kiss, pulls off. Oliver backs away from the curb, as the bus pulls in.  16.

Riding the bus. Oliver's sandwiched between an OLD JEWISH LADY and a PIERCED HIPSTER. He’s looking at a Mapquest print out. INSERT —- THE MAP: AN “X” MARKS THE SCHOOL’S LOCATION - ST. FRANCIS de SALES.
PACKS OF STUDENTS mosey towards the campus. A classic brick and stone Catholic School.

St. Francis de Sales Catholic School is just like any other middle school. Diverse. Modern. Noisy. Dozens of KIDS crowd the hallways, dig through lockers, socialize with FRIENDS. Oliver can’t open his locker. He tries the combination again...no dice. He looks around for help. No one makes eye contact. The tardy bell chimes. Oliver gives up, drags all his stuff with him. Rushes down the hallway. INT. BROTHER CRESPI’S CLASSROOM - MOMENTS LATER Religious Studies class. Brother Crespi stands in front of THIRTY CHATTY PRETEENS. Crespi’s in his thirties, preppy and full of new teacher idealism. Oliver stands at his side, he could pass out.
Settle down. I know it’s hard to come back to school after three weeks of vaca...but your education must continue. Believe me, you need it. The kids settle in.
This is Oliver. He’s joining us mid-stream here at St. Francis. We're happy to have him. Aren't we..? The CLASS speaks in unison, albeit bored and cynical.
Welcome to St. Francis, Oliver.  17.
Such genuine caring. Okay, Oliver, why don’t you lead us in morning prayer? Shit. Oliver is frozen. The class stares.
Everyone does it sooner or later. Oliver’s turning red. He leans in to Brother Crespi, whispers something in his ear.
I think I’m Jewish.
Okay. That’s good. (to the class) Oliver thinks he’s Jewish. A few KIDS speak out.
(on top of each other) So am I. I’m Buddhist. There is no God. Brother Crespi raises his hands before it gets out of control.
We celebrate all religions in this classroom. That’s why we’re called... The kids complete:
(with fun sarcasm) Religions of the World, with Brother Cary Crespi.

Bravo. Now, I happen to be Catholic, which is the very best religion in the world. Because we have the most rules. But some of us are Buddhist, Agnostic, Baptist, Presbyterian, Christian, and “I don’t know.” Which seems to be the fastest growing religion on the planet. And now we have Oliver. Who “thinks he’s Jewish.” Which is a new one for us as well. But...it doesn’t preclude you from morning prayer duty. Bow your heads. Heads down. Oliver has no idea where to begin. Crespi whispers to him:  18.
Say anything you want. Doesn't have to be special. Oliver bows his head.
Dear... Silence.
(whisper) God...etc, etc.
Dear God. Thank you. More silence.
(whisper) Amen.
Amen. The class repeats.
Amen. Oliver breathes. Crespi smiles at him.
You made it. Go grab your seat. Oliver walks to his desk.
Let's wipe the dust off that textbook, young ones. Chapter twelve. Catholic Saints. Books shuffle. Pages turn. Oliver sits down. Beyond embarrassed.
Horse track. Shitty cars litter the lot.
Vin’s filing out his race form. He closes his eyes, puts the form to his temple. Channels the racing gods. It’s his ritual.  19.
A TRUMPETER sounds the BUGLE CALL as JOCKEY’S on HORSES settle in their stalls. The gates open...and they’re off. Vin’s sitting in “his” booth. Eating lunch. Drinking. He’s always drinking.
Come on. Come on. Dig in. The horses fly around the track.
Dig. One time. One damn time. And just like that, Vincent’s horse...loses.
Son of a bitch. He crumples up his race form. Throws it on the floor. It lands at a MAN’S FEET.
No need to get pissy, Vincenzo. You lose all the time. Should be comfortable by now. Vincent looks up and sees...Zucko. His bookie. Dirty fingernails. Hairy eyeballs.
Yeah. Rough day. Zaucko sits. Takes a pull of Vin’s Maker's.
Help yourself.
I'm thirsty, Vin. And you owe me.
I don’t have it right now, kid. Got a situation I’m working out.
The thing is, if you’re breathing, we all have situation. I’m not a sole proprietor here, Vinny. Got my own people to answer to. You know that.
I just need a little time, you know.  20.
What do I tell ‘em?
A month.
I always loved your jokes. They kill me. You’re funny, Vin.
I always pay, don’t I? Zucko hits Vin’s Makers again.
Split the difference. Ya got two weeks. Zucko stands.
I hear the inside on the fifth is “Lucky By Numbers.” Right. But you got your luck. So. Go the other way. He leaves. Vin pushes his lunch aside. Appetite gone.

Gym class. Oliver’s straining with all his might, trying to do a sit-up. A PARTNER holds his feet. On the mat next to him, ROBERT OZINSKI, the school bully reps through sit-ups like a rabid Marine. COACH MITCHELL blows the whistle, asks the PARTNERS for the count. Oliver’s Partner holds up one finger.
Relay races. Ozinski sprints past the finish line. He’s a specimen for a twelve-year-old. Oliver is at the farthest end of the track. Running in slow motion. He’s lapped by a SMALL ASIAN GIRL.

Ozinski’s ripping off chin-ups like a baboon. As a- matter-of-fact, he looks like one. KIDS count off: fifteen, sixteen, seventeen. Oliver’s on the next bar, shaking like a leaf. He may die.  21. Finally, COACH MITCHELL blows the whistle. Oliver’s Partner holds up a goose egg.
Time. All right. Good job, kiddos. Ozinski drops to the floor.
We're done. Exodus towards the lockers. Coach Mitchell taps Oliver, who’s still hell-bent on getting his chin to that bar. It’s not going to happen.
You can let go now. Oliver looks down at the drop. He’s chicken shit. Coach grabs him by the back, lowers him like a feather.
Thank you.
You have PE at your last school?
Yes, sir.
Did you take it?
Yes, sir.
Go get changed. Oliver walks away, in the wrong direction.
The other way. Those doors. He stops, looks. Changes direction.
Oliver enters the locker room. Most of the KIDS are fully dressed already, and leaving. Ozinski starts heckling the moment he sees Oliver.
There’s the strong man. Laughs. One of Ozinski’s buddies (BROOKLYN) chimes in.  22.
“I think I’m Jewish.” More laughs. Oliver takes a seat in front of his locker.
My name is Oliver.
(like a retard) My name is Oliver. Just then Coach walks in.
You guys hear that bell? Silence.
That means get moving. Shuffling.
Go on. Get to class. They're off.
(to Oliver) You need a map? Oliver nods.
No, sir.
Double time it or you'll be late. Oliver nods. Coach walks off. He opens his locker. It’s empty. His pants, uniform...everything’s gone.

Shit. EXT. ST. FRANCIS DE SALES —- SIDEWALKS - LATER School's out. KIDS everywhere: jumping in cars, riding bikes, walking home. It's easy to spot Oliver in the crowd, he’s the only student wearing short gym shorts, a tank top and sneakers.  23. As expected, STUDENTS comment, laugh, text, chide. It’s not been a good first day for Oliver. He reaches the crosswalk. Looks up at the street sign, it doesn’t look vaguely familiar. He crosses anyway.

-- Oliver crosses a major Boulevard. Cars everywhere. -- He stops in the middle of a block. Looks around. Then turns and goes back in the direction from wince he came. -- Oliver walks in front of a row of houses. A DOG tears up and jumps on the picket fence, barking. Oliver runs off. -- Oliver reads a street sign. Thinks. Walks on. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Vin’s driving through major traffic. He pulls up next to a bus load of PUBLIC SCHOOL KIDS. They stare at him. He stares back. The light turns green, the bus pulls off. Then in tandem, the WHOLE WINDOW ROW OF KIDS flip him off. Damn kids. Vin lights a cigarette.

Finally, Oliver recognizes his block. He runs towards what he thinks is his house. Looks...that’s it. He’s home. EXT. MAGGIE & OLIVER’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Oliver, at the front door, reaches into his pocket for the key. Damn. He’s not wearing his pants. His key and phone were in the pockets of his stolen uniform. He could cry. But he’s not the type. He slumps down in resignation and sits on the cold concrete steps. VIN’S DRIVEWAY - CONTINUOUS Vin’s car pulls in haphazardly. He runs over some of the toppled fence. Curses, with the windows up...so it sounds like Charlie Brown’s parents. Vin climbs out of the car. Walks to the fallen mailbox, lowers himself onto the lawn, pulls mail out until...  24.
Sir? Vin hears something. Stops, looks around. Confused.
Take me, God. Don’t play with me. Oliver steps forward, down the walk.
It’s me, sir. Vin squints. Finally sees the kid.
Yeah. What?
I was wondering if I could use your phone?
My phone?
Yes.
In my house?
Yes.
For what?
To call my mom. I’m locked out. I was in gym class and these kids took my pants and I had my- Vin cuts him off.
I don’t need the whole story. Vin stares at the little shit. Pulls himself up off the lawn.

One call. Vin walks away. Oliver walks across the lawn and through the demolished fence into Vin’s yard.  25. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Oliver’s on an old rotary phone in the kitchen. Vin’s fixing a Maker’s Mark in the background. Ring. Ring. Ring. Voicemail.
Hi, Mom. I...ah...lost my key for the house. So, I’m at the old guy’s next door. Oliver turns to Vin.
Sir...what’s your name?
Vincent.

Vincent. (whispers ) The mean one... The conversation trails. VIN’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Vin’s sitting in his La-Z-Boy, facing Oliver on the couch. Felix the Cat is sitting in Vin’s lap, staring at Oliver. They don’t get much company around here. The silence lasts forever. And ever. A little longer. Then...
What’s your name?
Oliver. More silence.
Don’t you think it’s a little cold for shorts?
It’s a long story, sir.
I’m sure it is. Silence.  26.
I don’t like “sir.”
Sorry, sir.
It’s okay. Hmm. The phone rings. THE KITCHEN — CONTINUOUS Vin picks up the phone.
Yes.
The CAT scan lab. Maggie’s in scrubs, whispering in the corner of the room. ANOTHER NURSE is manning the controls, as a PATIENT (seen through the glass) is slid into the
tube.
This is Maggie, Oliver's mom. Is this Vincent?
Your kid’s here.
Yes. I just got his message. Is that all right?
Is what all right?
That he stays there?
Stays here. Like what, stays here?
I’m at work and...we got a few more cases. So, I don’t get off for a couple of hours and I can’t get him the key anyway. I’m ina little bit of a bind right now...
You want me to baby-sit?  27.
Well, he’s hardly a baby. He won’t bother you. He’1ll just do his homework. Oliver walks into the kitchen.
Sir? Vin holds up his hand, shushes Oliver.
What’re you paying?
Excuse me?
For baby-sitting. I’m not a philanthropy.
Okay...ten dollars an hour.
Twelve. Maggie is amazed.
Fine. Great. Can I talk to him? Vin puts the phone down on the counter, walks off.
Hey. It’s for you. Oliver walks to the phone, picks it up.
Oliver and Vin are sitting on the couch watching an old Abbott & Costello movie. Vin’s smoking, drinking. Felix the Cat is sitting in Oliver’s lap. Vin’s not thrilled.
He doesn’t like many people.
I’m good with animals, sir.
Yeah. He doesn’t usually like people who say they’re good with animals.  28. Oliver laughs at the movie. It’s rare.
You've never seen Abbott & Costello?
No, sir. Are they old?
No. They’re dead. That’s the oldest you can be.
Or the youngest. Time freezes when you die. Hmm.
Where’d you learn that?
A book.
What book?
A kid's book, sir. I doubt you know it. Little shit. Then...
It’s dinner time. You hungry or something? Oliver looks at Vin, studies his face.
A little, sir. Vincent looks annoyed. He’s the kind of guy that gets annoyed when someone wants something, even if he offered.

That figures. KITCHEN - VIN’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Vin’s scouring the kitchen, looking for something to feed the kid. All he finds is a tin of sardines and a package of Saltines. He cracks the sardines open. Arranges like it’s sushi. Decorates a dirty plate with concentric circles of sardines and stale crackers. Not bad.  29.

Oliver’s eating a sardine cracker sandwich. Watching the movie. Perfectly at home. Vin’s drinking his dinner, a huge stack of mail sitting on his lap. Bank statements, overdraft notices. He rips them up, one by one. His idea of filing. The doorbell rings.
Probably your mother.
Probably, sir. Oliver doesn’t move.
I guess I’ll get that.
Thank you, sir. Vin aches his way out of the recliner.
Vin peeks out the peep hole, then opens the door for...Maggie.
Hi. Vincent.
Yep. He doesn’t instinctively let her in.
Thank you so much for watching Oliver. I just started a new job and...
I don’t need the whole story.
Ok. Right. Maggie digs in her purse and pulls out some cash.
Here. Three hours. Twelve dollars an hour-
Thirty six.  30.
Yes, I know. She hands him two twenties.
I don’t have change. Of course. Really.
That’s...fine. Vin counts the money, puts it in his shirt’s breast pocket.
Where's his father? That’s personal.
Well. That’s a long story...see...
Don’t worry about it then. A beat. We hear Oliver laughing in the background. Maggie smiles.
How come you don’t have anyone to watch this kid after school?
We just moved in-
I was there.
Right.
You gonna pay for my fence?
Of course.
And the tree?
The tree? How-
Everything has a price. You're an adult, you should know that.
Okay. How much?

Vincent.

Sure. Then...
Ma, are we still Jewish? INT. BROTHER CRESPI’S CLASSROOM - CONTINUOUS Crespi, teaching.

Rachele. A tiny ASIAN GIRL answers.

Keesha.

St. Jude.

Mother Theresa.

Excellent. So...saints are human beings we celebrate for their dedication and commitment to other human beings. For their sacrifices. Their work to make society better for those around them and those that’1l come after them. A KID calls out from the back.
You're a saint, Brother Crespi.

Lockers. Maggie is packing up to go home after a long shift. Her supervisor, GLEN, finds her.
Maggie.
Hi.

School pickup. Oliver’s an ant amongst the THRONGS OF KIDS waiting for a ride home. He’s buried in a book, when Vin’s car putters in. A thorn amongst the black Crossovers. Vin scans the CROWD OF KIDS, spots Oliver. Honks his horn. Way too long. Everyone stares. Oliver looks up. Mortified. INT. VIN’S CAR - LATER Vin’s driving. Oliver’s still recovering. You’re not buckled.

Standard Operating Procedure. You go where I go. Do what I say. Get your homework done somewhere along the way. And most importantly, don’t annoy me. I’m not happy when I’m annoyed.
Are you annoyed right now?
Not particularly.
Really. Vin stares at him. Smart ass.
Vin pulls into a convenience store. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Parks.
Here’s a quarter. Call your mom, tell her you’re wearing your seat belt.
Costs more than a quarter.
Since when.
Since before I was born.
What’s wrong with this country. Vin digs some more change out of the ashtray.  38.
If it’s more than that, call collect. Vin's out, to the 7-Eleven.
Oliver’s dialing a number, when FOUR KIDS ON SKATEBOARDS round the corner. It’s Ozinski, Brooklyn and TWO OTHER PUNKS. Oliver turns his back. That won’t work. They wheel right up.
Hey. It’s dipshit.

Probably got detention cause a you. Asshole.

How do you know I took it? Ozinski flips his skateboard into his hand, moves in. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Fucking narc. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Vin’s back at the car. Leaning on his door, smoking a cigarette. Watching Oliver get knocked around. It’s entertaining for him. And embarrassing.
Ozinski slams Oliver hard into the payphone. His nose starts bleeding.
You're a bleeder.
I got a band-aid.  39. Oliver does the unimaginable: he swings at Ozinski. Well, rather, he slaps him in the face. Ozinski barely moves.
What was that supposed to be?
He just slapped you. Oliver tries to run. Brooklyn slides his skateboard under him, and the little guy goes flying to the pavement. Ozinski rolls up. Wheelies his board, pins Oliver's chest.
Please...that hurts. From around the corner, Vin’s voice.
What’re you little shit heels doing? They turn to see Vincent, holding a tire iron.
That you Robert Ozinski?
No, sir. My name’s John.
Bullshit, you little prick. You’re Reesa’s kid. Reesa Ozinski. I recognize you from your fat Polish nose. Vin walks towards them.
Just like your prick father’s nose. Guess the apple doesn’t fall too far from the rotten tree. Vin lights a cigarette.
I got a deal for you little bully shits. Whatever you do to the little guy there...I’m going to all of your mothers. Vin smashes a skateboard with the tire iron. It shatters.
Ride this!  40. Scared to shit, the four haul-ass out of there. VINCENT (CONT’D) Get on, pencil dicks! Vin walks up to Oliver. Looks down at him. Offers his hand. Oliver hesitates.
You need a paper invitation? Oliver takes his hand. Vin pulls him up to his feet, heads to the car. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Driving.
Who taught you...how to slap?
I don’t know. Just an instinct, I guess.
Well, you should unlearn that. Vin lights a cigarette.
I'm allergic, sir.
To what?
Cigarette smoke. Vin rolls down his window, hangs his cigarette outside. Keeps smoking.
Your father never taught you how to take care of yourself?
No, sir. He’s a pacifist.
Kid, this country wasn’t founded by tree huggers. That’s for sure. You gotta stand up for yourself or you get mowed down.
I’m small, if you haven’t noticed.  41.
So was Hitler.
That’s not a great comparison.
Indeed. Making a point though, fella. Small means nothing. It’s what you got in here. Vin points to his head.
Or here, sir. Oliver points to his heart. Vin looks at the little fella. This kid’s got something.
An expensive, well-kept convalescent center. Vin'’s car pulls in and parks in a handicapped spot.
Vin and Oliver are walking down the hallway. Oliver's carrying the laundry basket. Vin’s putting on a lab coat, carrying an old-school, leather doctor's bag.
This is like a mansion.
When we get in there, don’t talk.
Where are we going?
How about you practice not talking now. Vin turns a corner.
A WOMAN lies in a bed, watching TV. This is Vin’s wife. SANDY. She has advanced Alzheimer's. Vin and Oliver enter.
There you are, doctor.
Good to see you, Sandy.  42. Vin puts his doctor’s bag on the foot of her bed, digs in it. VINCENT (CONT’D) How're we feeling?
Today's my birthday. It’s not. Vin pulls out an old stethoscope.
Okay. Well, happy birthday. (to Oliver) Put that stuff in the drawers over there. Oliver complies.
Let’s see what the old ticker sounds like. Vin moves bedside, puts the stethoscope to Sandy’s chest.
Can you tell them I don’t like the green beans, when they put the bacon bits chopped up in there with them. It’s too greasy for me. Vin moves some hair off Sandy’s face. Lightly touches her cheek.
You bet, Sandy.
“Doctor” Vin and Oliver are sitting on a bench next to Sandy (in a wheelchair,) in front of a gorgeous pond, cluttered with ducks.
They say I’m going home next week. They don’t.
That’s the plan. It’s not.
Is that your grandson?
Nope.  43. Sandy looks Oliver over.
Is he a doctor?
Sure.

I don’t know.
Vin’s talking with Sandy’s nurse, ANA, a kind-eyed Filipino lady in her forties. She hands him a bundle of dirty laundry.

Gives me something to do. Vin hands the laundry off to Oliver.
Who’s your helper?

It’s Oliver actually.
Nice to meet you, Oliver. I’m Ana. Vin heads off. Stops.

I’1l make a note, Mr. Vincent. Ana writes in a pad.

INT. VINCENT’S GARAGE - LATER Oliver’s standing in a fight stance across from Vin, who’s wearing a bandana, holding a Maker’s Mark in one hand while leaning against a hanging heavy bag. Oliver punches the bag. It’s like a butterfly kiss.
That's just going to get you beat up real bad.

No one wants to fight, kid. You think I wanted to go to war? You think an eighteen year old wants to sit in a rice paddy while bullets are screaming past his ears on both sides?
When was that?
Vietnam.
You were there?

No, I’m imagining it. Vincent steps back, thinks. VINCENT (CONT’D) All right. I’11 teach you one thing, it’s probably the only hope you got. If you do it right, you'll break his nose with one shot. Oliver is rattled.
Break his nose.
Relax, you won’t do it right.
Maggie’s walking to her car after work. She’s exhausted. Just as she puts her key in the door...a MAN walks up.
Maggie?  45. She turns, clutches her purse.
I have mace.

LA County Family court. He hands the papers to Maggie. She hates taking them.

I didn’t mean to scare you. Just a job. Maggie nods, leans against the car. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER It's late. Maggie knocks on Vin’s door. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - LATER Vin’s leading Maggie into the den.
I’m working up an estimate on the fence. And we’re looking at three hundred on the tree. Not gonna negotiate with myself.
I get paid at end of next week.

That could've gone either way.

Classic dumpy titty-bar in a rundown industrial strip. Vin’s sitting in his car in the parking lot. Waiting. Daka eventually comes rolling out a side door. Spots Vin. Walks his way. INT. VIN’S CAR - CONTINUOUS Daka hops in, pissed.
Who pissed in your Cheerios?
I can dance no more.
That a surprise?
Fuck you, Vin. I need this money.

I should sue these. It’s...the word...discrimination. Against the pregnant woman. Yes?

The sex of the baby?

They have technologies-—

I know what they have. Maybe I ask “employer” to fax insurance card to pay ultrasound. Yes? Vin gets it. INT. OBGYN’S EXAMINING ROOM - LATER Daka has her legs up in stirrups, as an ULTRASOUND TECH squirts gel on her belly in preparation for an ultrasound.

Sorry. Forgot to tell you that. It’s cold. But just for a minute. The Tech places the wand on Daka’s belly. ULTRASOUND TECH (CONT’D) I’m gonna move this around here and take some pictures of the baby.
For taking pictures?
Well. Sort of. More like images. (motions to the monitor) Daka looks at the monitor. ULTRASOUND TECH (CONT’D) It’s pretty cool. See...there... Right...there. That’s the head.
This is very big head. Maybe good.
Biggest part at this age. Adjusts the wand. ULTRASOUND TECH (CONT’D) And these are her little legs.
She? You see this?
Oh, it’s a girl. You didn’t know? I'm sorry, did you not want to know? Daka could cry. But she won’t, she’s far too tough.
No. It’s good to know. INT. OBGYN’S LOBBY - LATER Vin and Daka are checking out with a MEDICAL RECEPTIONIST. Vin is digging through his wallet.
What’s my deductible running?
I couldn't verify her with your insurance, Mr. Canatella.  49. Daka butts in.
We are just married.
That happened.
Really?

Don’t let him started. The Receptionist doesn't believe a word of this.
What’s that deductible run?
Twenty dollars. Daka puts her head on Vin’s shoulder. Plays the part.

(under his breath) You owe me, lady. INT. ST. FRANCIS DE SALES - GYMNASIUM —- CONTINUOUS Dodge ball in progress. TWO TEAMS OF BOYS compete, throwing the ball as hard as they can at each other. Get ready for a red ass, shit bag. He runs. Throws. Oliver jumps. The ball bounces under him and hits the wall, heading back towards Ozinski.  50. Oliver runs for the ball, as fast as his fawn legs will take him. It’s like slow motion. At the half line...the ball is feet away from crossing back onto Ozinski’s side. Oliver dives for it. Thud. He lands hard on the gym floor, his face smacks the half line. Ozinski grabs the ball. Smiles. Runs toward Oliver. OZINSKI (CONT’D) Say your prayers, you little pussy. Ozinski winds up. Oliver stands, trying to get the hell out of there. Ozinski’s a few feet away. He hurls the ball at Oliver's mug... Thwwapppppp. Right on the kisser. This is bad. Oliver’s glasses fly off his head. You mother fucking, ass-face, dick bag... He has the wildest, animalistic look in his eyes. And he’s running directly at Ozinski. The entire class is frozen in disbelief...what the hell is he doing?

Asshole, cock sucking, son-of-a- whore... With his hand in a sort of death grip-blow, he hits Ozinski square in the nose...driving his schnoz up into his brain. Splickkkk! VIN’S HOUSE - LATER Oliver runs up to the house, bangs on the front door. Waits. Bangs again. Waits. Finally, Daka opens the door, wearing one of Vin’s old robes.

Fuck face is yeller. INT. VIN’S HOUSE - THE DEN - LATER Vin and Daka are sitting on the couch. Oliver’s standing in front of them, his eyeglasses are patched together with tape.

A lady of the night.

One of the more honest ways to make a living.

What’s 20 slash 1?  53.

Twenty times your money.

Vin and Oliver stand at the fence, watching HORSES and JOCKEYS walk. Beat.
(re: a horse) That one there with the wraps...is The kid is fast. a dog.

What’s a-
You see what I’m doing here?
Praying?  54.
Praying?

You pick three horses to finish 1-2- 3, in the order they come in. High risk, high reward.

Son-of-a-bitch. Vin kicks his chair, walks off. Oliver follows.
Mother fuckers. Zucko shakes his head at the losers.
(under ) Ease up there.

Vin’s practically running. Ducking in, out, around and between cars, a plastic shopping bag in his hand. Oliver’s on his tail. INT. VIN’S CAR - LATER A wad of cash sits between the two. $5,600 to be exact.
Your mom can’t know about this.
Exactly. Oliver nods.  56.
She could really use it though.

You keep my half for me? Vin knows that’s not smart.

What am I going to do with it? INT. THE BANK — CONTINUOUS Vin and Oliver sit at the banker’s desk, waiting. Terry strolls up.
Good afternoon. He recognizes Vincent.
Mr. Canatella.
Kind of you to remember. Need to open up a savings account for my grandson here. Terry has a seat. Vin slides a stack of cash across the desk.
Never too young to start banking. Vin slides over a few more bills
And this'll get my account back to zero. Close me out, while you’re tapping away there. Vin smiles a fuck you at him.

Vin is dancing solo to Steely Dan's, “Do It Again.” He’s wasted. Maker’s in one hand, a smoke in the other. His dance is a bizarre mix of slow-motion Tai Chi moves and yoga poses. In it we see the punch he taught Oliver. From the bar, Oliver watches. Perplexed.

Celebration dinner. Vin and Oliver are bellied up to the bar, eating a feast of bar food. Burgers, fries, mozzarella sticks, onion rings, Coke, a few Maker's Marks. Oliver slurps his drink to the bottom.

Yes, please.
Go for it. We’re living today. Oliver calls out weakly to the bartender (Roger.)
Excuse me, sir.
You kids. Damn small talkers. No point in yapping if nobody's listening. Let’s hear it. Oliver belts out.
Excuse me, sir.
Can't get nothing in this life without being heard. Roger walks over.
Another Coke, please.
You can hit me while you’re at it there to, Rog. Roger knows Vin is wasted.  Vin digs process. drink. 58.

Don’t lie to me, Roger. Be a man.
Vin. And he shouldn't be sitting at the bar. some cash out of his pocket. It’s a slow He tosses too much on the bar. Grabs his

Turncoats. Everywhere you look. No loyalty anymore. Everyone taking care of themselves in the old U.S. of A. That’s why we’re falling apart. Vin drains his wet ice, then smashes his glass on the bar. It shatters. His hand is ripped open.
Damnit, Vin.
Just a cut, pal. I’ve had a lot of them. Vin gets woozy, leans into Oliver.

Let’s get you home, kiddo. Got homework to do. He passes out. EXT. VIN’S HOUSE - NIGHT - LATER A taxi pulls into the driveway. The headlights illuminate a very pissed off Maggie, standing on Vin’s lawn. Vin and Oliver climb out of the car. Vin’s hand is bandaged.  59.
Hi, mom.
(to Vin) Where the hell’s your car?
It broke down.
It broke down.
Really. I don’t appreciate you taking him anywhere without asking me.
This is gonna be fun.
Don’t be a smart ass for once. I need to know where my son is at all times, okay? Oliver slumps off. Oliver goes inside.
We went to eat.
He should starve?
Get inside Oliver.
Mom-
Go on.
Good night, Vin.
We'll see.
He’s fighting at school. You know about this?
Mentioned something like that.  60.
Great. He tells you. Not his mother.
If you haven’t noticed...you’re not home much. Kinda hard to have a conversation with someone who’s not there.
I love it when people like you give people like me advice. Especially parenting advice.
I didn’t sign on for hormones here, deary. That’1ll cost you 15 bucks an hour.
You don’t have kids. You don’t have anything to think about but yourself. Vin starts to walk away.
What do you know about me? Really? Tell me. I’d love it. Vin stops. Maggie thinks.
Okay. You're right. I don’t know a whole lot about you. Because you don’t want much known. So you act like a prick and everyone stays away.
If it ain’t broken...
It is broken. Look at it. Vin goes into his house. Gets the last word in before he closes the door.
I’m up to 40 hours this week. 41 starts time-and-a-half. He’s gone.
Oliver’s sitting on a bench outside the Principal's office.  61. Across from him, Ozinski’s sitting with his MOTHER (REESA.) Ozinski’s nose is bandaged like a prize fighter’s.
(to Oliver) You're a real tiny fella, aren’t ya.
Yes, ma'am.
You take Judo or something. Ozinski is embarrassed.
Ma.
Shut your face. You don’t talk for a month. Ozinski slumps.

I'm glad it was a little shit that knocked the snot outta-ya. Now ya got no excuses. INT. PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Maggie’s sitting across from PRINCIPAL O'BRIEN, a puffy- faced official looking gent in his fifties. Maggie’s reading a report.
I can’t even say these words.
They’re...creative.

That’s one way to put it. PRINCIPAL O’BRIEN Adjusting to a new school is tough on children at this age. At any age. So, I don’t want to minimize that...but is there anything else going on that we should be aware of?
I don’t even know where to start.
How about his father?  62.

Oh. Well. Please. That’1l take up your whole day. We’re in the middle of a divorce. Oliver's father...was sleeping with his assistant. And our accountant. And her assistant. And my hairdresser. While she was still cutting my hair. That was fun. Now he’s filed for custody of Oliver. Full custody. And he won't pay support till he gets his way. You see. Plus he’s a lawyer, so. So. I just took Oliver away as fast as I could and took this job at Mission Hills. I’m a CAT scan tech, so I see a lot of rough situations. Tumors. Cancer. Cysts. Clots. All that. And of course, I know what I see and I can’t say anything to people. Which is miserable, as you can imagine. And I work really late, trying to get our act together. Give Oliver a better education and a semi- normal life. And fight David and this custody shit. Excuse me. That’s his name. David. My ex. He never wanted kids anyway. He just doesn’t want me to be happy. Oliver's adopted. Do you know that? How would you. I’m not able to have kids. Something about my Fallopian tubes being twisted. I think they were just recoiling from David's sperm. Maggie reaches for a tissue.
Do you mind? Principal O’Brien shakes his head “no.” He has no words.
I’m sure all of this has permeated into Oliver’s little being. And as they do in these situations...he’s acting out. Right? Principal O’Brien smiles. Maggie blows her nose.
